sub_title: PhD candidate Computational Geometry | MSc Computing Science | BSc Mathematics
summary:
My main interest is theoretical computer science, in particular the fields Computational Geometry and Programming Language Theory, through anything algorithmic is interesting to me. I like to solve complex theoretical problems, as well as implementing solutions programmatically.

Starting from September I will be a PhD candidate in the field of Computational Geometry, at Utrecht University and Eindhoven University of Technology. The research will look at different geometric and topological similarity measures for curves, and how to compute them.

Currently, I am working on making a paper out of my master's thesis, together with my thesis supervisors. For my thesis I have researched data structures for the chromatic k-Nearest Neighbors problem. This problem is closely related to the k-Nearest Neighbors classifier. My thesis contains the first results for this problem where the k nearest neighbors of a point are not computed explicitly.

projects:
[{'title': "Master's thesis - Chromatic k-Nearest Neighbors Queries using (Near-)Linear space", 'date': {'start': {'month': 11, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}, 'end': {'month': 6, 'day': None, 'year': 2021}}, 'description': "For my master's thesis I have researched the chromatic k-nearest neighbors problem. This problem is the geometric interpretation of the k-nearest neighbors classifier from machine learning. In the problem, we want to build a data structure on a set of colored points, such that given a query point q, the most frequently occurring color among the k-nearest neighbors of q can be found efficiently.
The thesis contains results for this problem under the L_1, L_2 and L_infty metrics, in one and two dimension(s), though the results can likely be generalized to other metrics and higher dimensions with already existing results.
Aside from data structures for the regular problem, the thesis contains semi-online data structures (dynamic data structures, in which we know the time at which a point is deleted), as well as approximation data structures, that report a color that occurs often enough.
The data structures have all been analyzed in terms of their asymptotic complexities (preprocessing time, space and query time). While the complexities of the standard data structures are on the high end, the approxiation data structures perform very well, achieving (near-)linear space, coupled with a query times that are almost O(sqrt(n)).", 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Thijs', 'last_name': 'van der Horst', 'name': None, 'headline': 'PhD candidate Computational Geometry | MSc Computing Science | BSc Mathematics'}]}, {'title': "Bachelor's Thesis - Pollard's Rho Algorithm on the GPU", 'date': {'start': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2019}, 'end': {'month': 6, 'day': None, 'year': 2019}}, 'description': "For my Bachelor's thesis, I researched Pollard's Rho algorithm for solving Discrete Logarithm problems. These problems have a great importance in Cryptography, and the subject has a very mathematical background, making it a suitable subject for my Mathematics Bachelor's thesis.
I ended up implementing Pollard's Rho algorithm on the GPU, in a way that accelerated the algorithm linearly in the number of threads used. Using a GPU, this meant a great improvement over the regular algorithm.
The thesis (in dutch) can be found here: https://dspace.library.uu.nl/handle/1874/382168", 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Thijs', 'last_name': 'van der Horst', 'name': None, 'headline': 'PhD candidate Computational Geometry | MSc Computing Science | BSc Mathematics'}]}, {'title': 'Simulationlibraries for the Dutch Railways (NS)', 'date': {'start': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2019}, 'end': {'month': 6, 'day': None, 'year': 2019}}, 'description': 'For my final project for the Computer Science bachelor, myself and 10 others have made a number of Python libraries for the Dutch Railways (NS), that they will use in their research into AI. The NS wants to use machine learning for the online-planning of their shunting yards, to better handle disturbances as they happen.
The main library is meant to give the possible actions one can take, given the current situation. It has a businessrule validator, to check if a state satisfies all constraints. Which constraints are used can be easily configured by the researchers. Also, the library lets the reasearchers create their own rules for maximum extensibility.
The other libraries are meant for seeing how robust a planning is, and for making the libraries available in other languages through gRPC.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Thijs', 'last_name': 'van der Horst', 'name': None, 'headline': 'PhD candidate Computational Geometry | MSc Computing Science | BSc Mathematics'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Marco', 'last_name': 'van de Weerthof', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Student bij Universiteit Utrecht'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Jonathan', 'last_name': 'den Herder', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Software Engineer @ ORTEC - Optimize Your World'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Hanno', 'last_name': 'Ottens', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Software Engineer at Arkey Systems '}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Luuk', 'last_name': 'Glorie', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Software Developer at Poort80'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Kasper', 'last_name': 'Zwijsen', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Head of Audits at Hexens'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Jens', 'last_name': 'Heuseveldt', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Student aan de/het Universiteit Utrecht'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Sjoerd', 'last_name': 'Crooijmans', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Software Developer at Bluenotion'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Loriana', 'last_name': 'Pascual', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Software Developer bij InTraffic'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Dennis', 'last_name': 'A.', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Student at TUE'}]}]
